item.title: The Week Ahead: September 13
item.description: California recall: CA Governor Gavin Newsom faces a high-stakes recall election on Tuesday. New iPhones: Tomorrow, Apple will hold its fall hardware event, where it’s expected to introduce the iPhone 13, new Apple Watches and AirPods, and more.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Remote Workers Get Siloed at their Companies, Microsoft Study Shows
item.description: Zoom out: The research was published as most of the country’s biggest tech companies push off a return to the office in light of the Delta variant.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Norway Heads to the Polls in Pivotal Election for the Environment
item.description: But unlike in the US, smaller political parties in Norway hold major sway.   And how those groups, which advocate for a more immediate break from fossil fuels, fare in the election will ultimately decide how quickly Norway severs ties to an industry that made it so rich.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Biden Expands Production of At-Home Covid Tests, Where the US Is Behind
item.description: Zoom out: Michael Mina, a Harvard epidemiologist who’s been arguing for more at-home tests since last year, said Biden’s plan was a “good start,” but by the numbers it still represents less than one test per American over the course of a year.  Even India, which has fewer resources than the US, is selling rapid tests for $3.50.  Problem is, in the US over-the-counter rapid tests are expensive and scarce.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.description: (Bloomberg)The man in the red bandana. (NPR)Prominent Muslim Americans reflect on the past 20 years.  — NF

item.title: Harvard Ends Its Investments in Fossil Fuel Industry
item.description: In a W for environmental activists, the richest university in the country said yesterday that it will no longer directly invest in fossil fuels.

item.title: Epic Games Wins Lawsuit Against Apple
item.description: The game was promptly booted from the App Store, and Epic launched its revolution with a 1984-style video and a lawsuit against Apple, which culminated in a high-profile trial featuring testimony from Apple CEO Tim Cook. The backstory: Last summer, Epic CEO Tim Sweeney martyred his top-earning game Fortnite by encouraging users to make in-game purchases (hamburger helmets, demogorgon skins) outside of Apple’s payment systems in protest of the steep commission Apple charges developers in its App Store.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

The backstory: Last summer, Epic CEO Tim Sweeney martyred his top-earning game Fortnite by encouraging users to make in-game purchases (hamburger helmets, demogorgon skins) outside of Apple’s payment systems in protest of the steep commission Apple charges developers in its App Store.

item.title: How is Covid Affecting Campus Life?
item.description: 58% of college students believe that their school should require vaccinations. Bella Mortel, a University of Texas at Austin Junior, said, “Seeing students and professors back on campus on the first day of school this year reminded me of how critical the in-person experience is! Only 28% of students had complete trust that their schools would keep them safe from Covid, while 47% of students said, “Yes, sort of.” Another ID to lose. Ben Klein, who started his third year at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, said, “I feel more comfortable that we have to wear masks and social distance during in-person classes, but at the end of the day if our area gets swamped with Delta, Mu, or some other variant, I think cases are inescapable. In a Morning Brew + Generation Lab poll, we asked 524 college students across the US about their experiences back on campus. Students definitely, maybe trust their school.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Icebreakers with...Master Sommelier Ian Cauble
item.description: But most people don't have that bottle of wine you found on that shelf in that specific wine shop. With just a 5% pass rate, the top wine test has snarled the dreams of all but 267 people who are able to call themselves a true Master. In 2012, Ian Cauble passed the wine world’s version of astronaut training to become one of only a few Master Sommeliers in the world. Why is wine the go-to dinner party gift? Most people start by working in restaurants for a very long time—a lot of them for more than 10 years by the time they pass the Master Sommelier exam. It’s a very easy gift and there's usually a great story behind it. I would say most wine is not designed to age.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Your 2021–2022 NFL Season Preview
item.description: The new NFL season kicks off with a full slate of games today. During the offseason, the NFL struck deals with seven sportsbook operators, which, among other things, allows them to buy commercial spots during NFL games for the first time ever. This season, Amazon Prime Video will share the rights with NFL Network and Fox for Thursday Night Football (TNF), but come 2022 you’ll be all Andy Jassy’s: Amazon will be the exclusive “broadcaster” for TNF for the next 10 years. More streamingAs part of the NFL’s new gargantuan media rights deal reportedly worth over $100 billion, streaming will play a bigger role. Gambling companies will make more money, football players will make more money, and the NFL itself certainly stands to gain from an extra slot for advertising, ticket sales, merchandise, and more.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The economic impact of 9/11, 20 years later
item.description: The Stock Market After 9/11Because of the digitization of trading, experts worry that a major cyberattack on Wall Street could be equally—if not more—devastating than September 11, 2001. The Death and Life of NYC’s Financial DistrictIn the years since September 11, 2001 many banks left the neighborhood, primarily for Midtown.
item.author: Gaetane Lewis

item.description: (Bloomberg)The man in the red bandana. (Esquire)Children of those killed on 9/11 are following their parents into finance—some at the same investment firms.

item.title: Stock Watch: September 12
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Make It Work: Building Strong Virtual Relationships
item.description: Having more recently begun a new job on a fully remote team, where the only radio playing at a “reasonable volume” is my own, your question got me thinking about the influence that an increasingly virtual workplace is having on team dynamics. Any advice/tips on how to build healthy professional relationships with new teammates? Something I’m doing with my current team is a rotating brown bag, whereby we use part of our weekly meeting for a team member to teach us something new. —Brandon from MinneapolisAs someone who relies on poor lighting in order to be the best-looking person on my video calls, I’m probably not the best source of advice on this one. Have a question about work you want to ask Shane?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: JPMorgan Says It will to Buy Restaurant-Discovery Service the Infatuation
item.description: Two powerful forces driving food spending—the Chase credit card suite and the restaurant review platform the Infatuation—are becoming one.  Bottom line: While this type of deal is rare, it isn't ~unprecedented~. And the number of travelers at US airports this summer was triple what it was a year ago.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 10
item.description: Quote: “I want a labor market so tight that you don’t even have to cover up your tattoos to get a job. (Aeon) US Rep. Brad Sherman of California told the WSJ in colorful terms why he supports the reappointment of Fed Chair Jerome Powell.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: It's Electric: The Stock Market After 9/11
item.description: The attacks on NYC’s World Trade Center struck the US financial industry’s central nervous system, where only blocks away from the towers thousands of traders bought and sold stocks at the New York Stock Exchange. For the final installment in the series, we’re going back to our roots and discussing 9/11’s impact on the stock market.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Facebook Launches Smart Glasses With Ray-Ban
item.description: Facebook launched its first-ever line of smart glasses in partnership with Ray-Ban yesterday. With the glasses, you can... For these smart glasses to gain traction, Facebook will have to convince consumers that they’re not unwitting characters in an episode of Black Mirror.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Biden’s New Vaccine Mandate Could Affect 80 Million US Workers
item.description: The president announced yesterday that all businesses with 100 or more workers will need to mandate vaccines or administer weekly tests for employees, potentially affecting 80 million US workers. And Biden’s not just taking aim at the private sector—all federal workers will need to get vaccinated within 75 days or face losing their jobs. Almost 30,000 children were hospitalized with Covid in August, the most ever reported to date, according to government health data. The government has tried everything else to convince more Americans to get vaccinated, and it hasn't worked."
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Biden’s New Vaccine Mandate Could Affect 80 Million US Workers
item.description: Biden announced yesterday that all businesses with 101+ workers will need to mandate vaccines or administer weekly tests for employees, potentially affecting 80 million US workers. And Biden’s not just taking aim at the private sector—all federal workers will need to get vaccinated within 75 days or face losing their jobs.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: It's Electric: The Stock Market After 9/11
item.description: The attacks on NYC’s World Trade Center struck the US financial industry’s central nervous system, where only blocks away from the towers thousands of traders bought and sold stocks at the New York Stock Exchange. For the final installment in the series, we’re going back to our roots and discussing 9/11’s impact on the stock market. Leading up to the anniversary of the September 11 attacks this Saturday, we’ll feature stories that explore the economic impact of 9/11, 20 years later.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: JPMorgan Says It will to Buy Restaurant-Discovery Service the Infatuation
item.description: In 2019, American Express acquired Resy, the restaurant reservation platform, in a bid to hold onto its card members amid fierce competition from other credit-card issuers.  Bottom line: While this type of deal is rare, it isn’t without precedent.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Lululemon Reports Better Than Expected Earnings
item.description: And recent patents show Lulu could be exploring wellness products that use biometric monitoring technology. Lululemon has already integrated Mirror, the at-home fitness company it bought last year, into 150 of its brick-and-mortar stores. Double down on becoming a "tech" company.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: September 9
item.description: (New Yorker) Read: In the Afghan countryside, the endless killing of civilians turned women against the occupiers who claimed to be helping them.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Examining the Pop Culture Legacy of the September 11 Attacks
item.description: Leading up to the anniversary of the September 11 attacks this Saturday, we’ll feature stories that explore the economic impact of 9/11, 20 years later. Before September 11, 2001, movies like Independence Day and Armageddon gleefully depicted the annihilation of American cities. — NF How long will it be before a director pitches a pandemic film?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Energy Department Report Says Solar Could Power Almost Half of US Electricity by 2050
item.description: The US Energy Department said that solar energy could power 44% of the country’s electricity by 2050, up from 3% currently, in a major report released yesterday.  Big picture: US solar installations grew a record 43% from 2019 to 2020, which means that 20% of the country’s entire solar capacity was installed last year alone.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: The SEC Threatens to Sue Coinbase
item.description: Coinbase contends that Lend doesn’t involve securities and called that assumption “strange.” In this case, the SEC says they’ll sue Coinbase if and when it launches Lend. That’s how Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong described the SEC’s latest crypto crackdown. In a blog post and a nowadays-mandatory Twitter thread, Coinbase executives said they don’t understand what grounds the SEC is suing them on, and that the SEC has refused to loop them in.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Home, Sweet Futuristic, Home: The Rise of High-Tech Consumer Products
item.description: ) But what’s really important to keep in mind is that whether it’s tech that cleans or tech that drives you to work—it’s all here to make our lives easier. Ultrasonic recognition tech gives you complete control. In terms of recognition of obstacles in the home, for example, AI allows machines to take in complex data and make sense of it on the fly. Compared to just camera-based navigation, LiDAR allows for a level of precision that can help your tech move like it’s actually, truly smart. And while some people are still standing on street corners wondering why they can’t hail a flying taxi, we’re here to talk about the futuristic tech that can be in your home today.  And while this tech can tell a product where they are, it can also tell it where not to go.
item.author: Morning Brew

item.title: Lululemon Reports Better Than Expected Earnings
item.description: what do you even do when you hit your revenue goals two years ahead of schedule? Last year, Lululemon bought at-home fitness company Mirror in hopes to be your ultimate workout buddy. Double down on becoming a tech company.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Energy Department Report Says Solar Could Power Almost Half of US Electricity by 2050
item.description: The US Energy Department said that solar energy could power 44% of the country’s electricity by 2050, up from 3% currently, in a major report released yesterday. Another barrier: How dependent the US solar industry is on China.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: The SEC Threatens to Sue Coinbase
item.description: But Coinbase says Lend doesn’t involve securities and called that assumption “strange.” In this case, the SEC says they’ll sue Coinbase if and when it launches Lend. Lend would let Coinbase users earn interest by lending digital assets—specifically, a stablecoin called USD Coin—to others. That’s how Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong described the SEC’s latest crypto crackdown. According to Coinbase, the Wall Street regulator has sent the leading crypto exchange a “Wells notice” regarding its upcoming lending product, Lend.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Examining the Pop Culture Legacy of the September 11 Attacks
item.description: Now, with villains once again razing cities in films like Batman v Superman, it appears that 9/11 imagery has become “subtext instead of text,” Vox wrote. Leading up to the anniversary of the September 11 attacks this Saturday, we’ll feature stories that explore the economic impact of 9/11, 20 years later. How long will it be before a director pitches a pandemic film?
item.author: Neal Freyman
